Entries.default: "Indulge me in a moment's curiosity. There is something I wish to know about Eora - about kith - that I can only learn through your eyes."
"What could I know that you don't?"
"Well look at that, now Eothas the green and terrible needs something from me."
"Go on."
"You're not taking my eyes. I need them."
"You followed me all this way, dodging an armada, navigating an impenetrable wall of storms..."
"You misunderstand."
"Yes."
"Forget it. I'm done talking."
"Very well."
"...besting a guardian who existed to bar your trespass..."
"...voyaging across uncharted seas..."
"...with the machinations of gods echoing in your ears..."
"...and you did so on your own. That is no small achievement. Kith across Eora will hear the tale of it and look to you with awe."
"...all the while trusting in the institutions of kith to get you this far - and earning their trust in turn. Whatever else happens this day, that much is remarkable."
"I believe that mortals possess the strength to collaborate and shape a future of their own design. Not all of my brothers and sisters agree."
"I had hoped your actions would set an example for the future, demonstrating the resilience and ingenuity of mortals when they work together."
"What inspired your decision, Watcher? Did the choice echo your foundational beliefs, or were you influenced by observation?"
"I believe that mortals possess the strength to collaborate and shape a future of their own design. Not all of my brothers and sisters agree."

"By relying on others and coming together in a time of crisis, you illustrate my point. The gods will witness you and question their assumptions about how responsible, empathetic, and sophisticated mortals can be."
"What inspired your decision, Watcher? Did the choice echo your foundational beliefs, or were you influenced by observation?"
"I believe in the Huana cause. Ukaizo will strengthen and unify the tribes."
"I wanted to prove Woedica wrong. She thinks mortal cooperation is destined to fail."
"I wanted justice for the Huana. Ukaizo is theirs to rule."
"Someone made me an offer and I took it. Nothing personal."
"What inspired your decision, Watcher? Did the choice echo your foundational beliefs, or were you influenced by observation?"
"What inspired your decision, Watcher? Did the choice echo your foundational beliefs, or were you influenced by observation?"
"What inspired your decision, Watcher? Did the choice echo your foundational beliefs, or were you influenced by observation?"
"Mortals couldn't work through their petty differences. I didn't have time to wait for them to see reason."
"I thought Woedica made a good argument. Collaboration is fine, but kith require a guiding hand."
"I didn't come to the Deadfire to settle the problems of others."
"I don't owe you any explanation."
"I thank you for your perspective. Yours is not the only opinion that concerns me, but for the moment it offers much to consider."
"Woedica has been especially active since the downfall of her favorite operative. Have you ever considered that she is mentoring his replacement?"
"Perhaps not. One day, I hope you are able to look beyond your misfortunes and behold a broader view of my motives."
"I work alone."
"We need ingenuity if we're going to survive. It was a logical choice."
"The Vailians have enough resources at their disposal to undo your damage."
"History is written by survivors. It would be irresponsible to prop up a lesser authority."
"Rauataians know how to respond to a threat. The future will need their cunning."
"The Pr√≠ncipi showed unity and willingness to adapt. They can bring the archipelago together."
"Strength rules the Deadfire. If that means piracy, so be it."
"You shirked the aid of others and came this far alone, but I think you'll find that the future is built on trust, cooperation, and understanding among kith."
"Never forget that trust and coordination between mortals brought you to this place. Your future is built on a foundation of hope, and you have laid the first stone."
"All I ever wanted for mortals was growth. Transformation. Once my brothers and sisters shared this goal."
"It brings me great sorrow that crisis is the only way to set the future in motion. Would that I could pass the responsibility of heralding your darkest hour to another."
"Thanks for the lesson. What happens next?"
"Before this is over, it's my turn to ask the questions."
"Ask. You are entitled to any answer that is mine to give."
"This has been a nice chat, but I was just buying time. Wael's titan should be here any second now."
"A titan approaches? I had thought them all..."
"No... The work continues. I can delay no longer."
"That's all. What happens next?"
"What happens after the Wheel breaks?"
"How long until Eora is devoid of all life?"
"Why won't reincarnation just go back to how it was before the Wheel?"
"How can anyone trust the gods after what you've done?"
"The great work of the Engwithans falls to ruin. Reincarnation, as we know it, will end."
"When we tamed the cycle of reincarnation, we broke what had once functioned naturally and without intervention. The flow of essence will not normalize on its own."
"Souls which currently await new life in the Beyond will be born into the world as normal, but their numbers will not replenish."
"Unless mortals work together to carve a new path, the essence of life will be trapped in the netherworld. Gods will starve. Eora will grow silent and cold."
"A generation or more. That much essence is already poised to flow into Eora. But unlike an hourglass, no amount of turning will compel the sand to reverse its course."
"By your reckoning, there are still good years to come. By ours, time is short."
"Should you choose, you could lay down your burden and trust in your children's children to set matters right. That depends entirely on you."
"Essence will simply pool in the void of the In-Between, never passing through adra networks to the Beyond. The dead will be left to wander in darkness, confusion, and sorrow."
"No one is worthy of unconditional trust. If you feel the gods are beyond forgiveness, then they don't deserve your obedience. Make your future one that doesn't require them."
"Should you choose to accept the gods, I hope that you temper your faith with skepticism."
"That's a... troubling thought."
"Beloved Woedica, the hour of our joining cannot come soon enough!"
"Interesting. I won't dismiss the idea entirely."
"My brothers and sisters never act when the gains are strictly short-term."
"If she deserves your love, then may you be favorable partners in the years to come."
[Say nothing.]
His gaze lingers on Aloth for a moment before turning back to you.
You feel searing heat radiate from Woedica's restored crown, but a moment later it cools.
"Woedica sees this as a test. One we're destined to fail."
"Woedica is entitled to her opinion. If the intent of this test is to justify an uprising to come, that is more worrisome."
"The other gods must decide for themselves if mortals are ready to dictate their future. Should Woedica's tyranny prove the only alternative, mortals must prepare for a terrible conflict."
"Your perspective bridges eternity, Watcher. Many will look to you to mediate differences that could shake the very foundations of Eora."
"Once the Beyond has emptied, every birth will be Hollowborn. Other maladies of the soul may follow and plague those who linger in life."
"Coming to Ukaizo unencumbered by alliances proves a different point than the one I intended, but it is a valuable one all the same."
"If Woedica's shadow has fallen upon you, that can only mean she recognizes your potential to further her ambition."
"Some have forgotten themselves, giving in to fatalism or tyranny. Others have succumbed to apathy."
"Anything that dies will tarry in the void of the In-Between, awaiting the motion of a Wheel that no longer turns."
"Mortals aren't the only ones in jeopardy. What you're doing threatens the gods."
"You've had millennia to do this. Why now?"
"I haven't forgiven you for Caed Nua."
"Yes. They must work toward a solution or perish."
"If that task is beyond their skill, then they no longer deserve their position. I would have them justify their right to lead."
"That could mean swallowing their pride and hearkening to the wisdom of mortals. Some, I expect, will perform better than others."
"For several reasons. My strength was diminished after the Godhammer Bomb, and assuming this form took incredible effort."
"With so many vying for control of the Deadfire, I also saw a ripe opportunity for mortals to cast aside their differences and stand together as one."
"They have never been more powerful, more capable. Because of this, the gods must justify their importance or be proven obsolete."
"I apologize, Watcher. There is nothing I can do to restore the glory of your hard-won and poorly-situated estate."
"Given your perseverence, I know that a second home cannot be distant in your future. You have only to seek it out."
"What happened to Caed Nua was not personal in nature. I would have occupied the statue even if it was buried beneath Defiance Bay."
